Week Week List FICTION
1 THE HOUSE, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $27.) A workaholic lawyer's life changes when she buys a crumbling mansion.
2 1 3 THE 5TH HORSEMAN, by James Patterson and Maxine Paetro. (Little, Brown, $27.95.) Detective Lindsay Boxer and the Women's Murder Club investigate unexplained deaths at a San Francisco hospital.

3 3 154 THE DA VINCI CODE, by Dan Brown. (Doubleday, $24.95; special illustrated edition, $35.) A murder at the Louvre leads to a trail of clues found in the work of Leonardo and to the discovery of a secret society.
4 2 6 CELL, by Stephen King. (Scribner, $26.95.) What remains of humanity fights to survive after a mysterious force scrambles cellphone users' brains.

5 4 2 THE TEMPLAR LEGACY, by Steve Berry. (Ballantine, $24.95.) A former Justice Department operative becomes involved in a desperate search for the long-lost treasure and secrets of the medieval Knights Templar.

6 5 7 THE LAST TEMPLAR, by Raymond Khoury. (Dutton, $24.95.) A coding device stolen from an exhibit of Vatican artifacts may hold clues to the medieval Knights Templar's long-lost treasure -- and their secrets.
7 7 3 IN THE COMPANY OF THE COURTESAN, by Sarah Dunant. (Random House, $23.95.) A courtesan and her pimp, a dwarf, make their way in Renaissance Venice.
8 6 2 THE TWO MINUTE RULE, by Robert Crais. (Simon & Schuster, $24.95.) A robber just released from prison tracks down the killers of his son, a Los Angeles cop.
1 SOUR PUSS, by Rita Mae Brown and Sneaky Pie Brown. (Bantam, $25.) Aided by her cats, a Virginia woman investigates a mysterious death.
1 THE REBELS OF IRELAND, by Edward Rutherfurd. (Doubleday, $28.95.) A story of six families against the sweep of Irish history from 1597 to 1922.
11 9 4 LOVERS & PLAYERS, by Jackie Collins. (St. Martin's, $24.95.) Red Diamond's three sons grapple with sex, secrets and murders on both coasts.
12 10 4 SEA CHANGE, by Robert B. Parker. (Putnam, $24.95.) Jesse Stone, the police chief of Paradise, Mass., searches for the killer of a woman whose body washed ashore.
13 8 2 THE OLD WINE SHADES, by Martha Grimes. (Viking, $25.95.) Richard Jury of New Scotland Yard investigates a disappearance that involves a murder.
14 11 6 MEMORY IN DEATH, by J. D. Robb. (Putnam, $24.95.) Lt. Eve Dallas tracks the killer of a woman who blackmailed her; by Nora Roberts, writing pseudonymously.
1 THE ISLAND, by Heather Graham. (Mira, $21.95.) A young woman on vacation discovers a skull and pursues its story; back home in Miami, she faces threats.
1 THE FALLEN, by T. Jefferson Parker. (Morrow, $24.95.) A San Diego detective investigates the death of a colleague in an atmosphere of municipal corruption.

Week Week List NONFICTION
1 1 20 MARLEY & ME, by John Grogan. (Morrow, $21.95.) A newspaper columnist and his wife learn some life lessons from their neurotic dog.

2 2 48 THE WORLD IS FLAT, by Thomas L. Friedman. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $27.50.) A columnist for The New York Times analyzes 21st-century economics and foreign policy and presents an overview of globalization.

3 3 47 FREAKONOMICS, by Steven D. Levitt and Stephen J. Dubner. (Morrow, $25.95.) A maverick scholar and a journalist apply economic theory to everything from cheating sumo wrestlers to legalized abortion and the falling crime rate.
4 5 4 MANHUNT, by James L. Swanson. (Morrow, $26.95.) The 12-day pursuit of John Wilkes Booth after his assassination of Abraham Lincoln.
5 4 6 YOU'RE WEARING THAT?, by Deborah Tannen. (Random House, $24.95.) How mothers and daughters communicate.
6 6 22 THE YEAR OF MAGICAL THINKING, by Joan Didion. (Knopf, $23.95.) The author's attempts to come to terms with the death of her husband and the grave illness of their only daughter.
7 9 57 BLINK, by Malcolm Gladwell. (Little, Brown, $25.95.) The author of ''The Tipping Point'' explores the importance of hunch and instinct to the workings of the mind.

8 7 19 TEAM OF RIVALS, by Doris Kearns Goodwin. (Simon & Schuster, $35.) The political genius of Abraham Lincoln, revealed in his relationship with his cabinet, from the author of ''No Ordinary Time.''
1 STRATEGERY, by Bill Sammon. (Regnery, $27.95.) A behind-the-scenes look at the election of 2004 and the following year from a Washington Times reporter. ()

10 14 3 BEYOND BAND OF BROTHERS, by Dick Winters with Cole C. Kingseed. (Berkley Caliber, $24.95.) The war memoirs of the commander of Easy Company, made famous by Stephen Ambrose's ''Band of Brothers.''
11 11 16 TEACHER MAN, by Frank McCourt. (Scribner, $26.) The author of ''Angela's Ashes'' remembers his years teaching high school English in New York City.
1 EAT, PRAY, LOVE, by Elizabeth Gilbert. (Viking, $24.95.) A writer's yearlong journey in search of self takes her to Italy, India and Indonesia.
13* 8 21 CONFESSIONS OF A VIDEO VIXEN, by Karrine Steffans. (Amistad/HarperCollins, $24.95.) A tell-all by an actress who has appeared in many hip-hop videos.
14 12 18 OUR ENDANGERED VALUES, by Jimmy Carter. (Simon & Schuster, $25.) The former president warns against blurring politics and fundamentalist religion.
15 13 22 MY FRIEND LEONARD, by James Frey. (Riverhead, $24.95.) Both author and publisher acknowledge that this book about Frey's helpful mobster friend contains numerous fabrications.

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ended March 4, at almost 4,000 bookstores plus wholesalers serving 50,000 other retailers, statistically weighted to represent all such outlets nationwide. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger () indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Expanded rankings are available at The New York Times on the Web: nytimes.com/books.
Editors' Choice
Other recent books of particular interest

FALLING THROUGH THE EARTH: A Memoir, by Danielle Trussoni. (Henry Holt, $23.) With affection, respect and humor, a daughter tries to make sense of the demons her father brought home from the Vietcong's subterranean labyrinth.

THE WEATHER MAKERS: How Man Is Changing the Climate and What It Means for Life on Earth, by Tim Flannery. (Atlantic Monthly, $24.) This guide to the complexities of climate change is strong on geological history. Passionate and well researched, as is the following:

FIELD NOTES FROM A CATASTROPHE: Man, Nature, and Climate Change, by Elizabeth Kolbert. (Bloomsbury, $22.95.) A global tour of the evidence, with scientists the author meets along the way doing most of the talking.
WHAT JESUS MEANT, by Garry Wills (Viking, $22.95.) In this devotional study, a noted scholar and Catholic stresses Christ's radicalism.
AVERNO, by Louise Glück. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $22.) Poems inspired by the underworld of myth confront our most intractable fears.
THE PEOPLE'S ACT OF LOVE, by James Meek. (Canongate, $24.) In a Siberian town in 1919, zealots, cannibals and penal colony inmates prefigure Russia's Communist future.

A DANGEROUS ENGINE: Benjamin Franklin, From Scientist to Diplomat, by Joan Dash. Illustrated by Dusan Petricic. (Frances Foster/ Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $17. Ages 10 and up.) Goes way beyond the key on the kite string.
CONSIDER THE LOBSTER: And Other Essays, by David Foster Wallace. (Little, Brown, $25.95.) Magazine articles with a moral framework.
MUSIC FROM BIG PINK: A Novella, by John Niven. (Continuum, paper, $9.95.) A Woodstock-era tale of human loss, backed up by the Band.
CRUNCHY CONS, by Rod Dreher. (Crown Forum, $24.) A reporter examines a class of conservatives with an ecological, countercultural bent.
WHAT CAROLINE KNEW, by Caryn James. (St. Martin's, $21.95.) A risqué painting of an alluring socialite kicks up a Jazz Age scandal.
The full reviews of these and other recent books are on the Web: nytimes.com/books.
